You don't like it, but you can't just get rid of it. It's a struggle. But you have to learn to deal with it or it'll make you insane.
I haven't had much success with fear. Sensing she needs some help as she works on him, Jack off

When I was in residency, my first solo procedure was a spinal surgery on a sixteen year-old kid. Girl. (beat) At the end of it -- thirteen hours later -- I was closing her up... and I... I accidentally ripped her dural sack -- you know what that is? Kate has stopped sewing, now staring at him.

It's at the base of the spine, where all the nerves come together. Membrane as thin as tissue. So it ripped open -- the nerves just spilled out like angel hair pasta-- her spinal fluid flowing out and I just... froze. 'Cause I knew. If I didn't get those nerves back in that sack and sew it up... those thirteen hours were for nothing, that girl would be paralyzed. I had about a minute. (beat) And all the assistants were just watching me, I could feel their eyes. And the terror was so... crazy, so real... and I knew I had to deal with it. So I just made a choice. I'd let the fear in. Let it take over. Let it do its thing. (looks at Kate) But only for five seconds. That's all I was gonna give it. So I started to count to five. I could feel it inside -- like when you drink a milkshake on a hot day. (beat) One, two, three, four, five. (beat) And it was gone. I got back to work. Sewed her up. She was fine. Kate breathes again, returns to stitching him. (CONTINUED)

I think everyone has something like that. A moment where you establish your relationship with fear. And either you learn to deal with it... or you don't. From Kate, a little, sad laugh:

The sun drops below the horizon. The sky turning a miraculous purple-red. Claire watches the sunset. At another part of the beach, Locke watches the sunset.

Pardon me for appearing desperate, but in case you didn't hear the pilot before he was eaten, they're never going to find us unless we get that thing to work. (deep breath, then) So is there anything?
No.
What were you doing. In the bathroom.
Oh, I thought you could tell. I was getting sick. Puking. My one... tangible contribution to this trek.
No, I'm glad you came. (CONTINUED)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  51.
Yeah, every trek needs a coward.
You're not a coward. And as they walk we're TIGHT ON CHARLIE, who considers th as they walk... and we HOLD TIGHT ON HIS FACE AS SOUNDS F
Are you all right, sir?
Back on the PLANE, PRE-CRASH. CHARLIE sits in his seat ne the rear of the plane, shaking. Pale. SWEAT dots his brow He looks up at the same FLIGHT ATTENDANT that helped Jack
Yeah -- I'm good, thanks.
Can I get you some wat--?
(go away) I'm fine. Thank you. Please. The Flight Attendant stares. Then:
All right. As she heads to the back of the plane, she looks at him, maybe a little SUSPICIOUSLY. Charlie taps his hand, FIDGETY. Takes a quick peek over h shoulder at --

The Flight Attendant who he just blew off talks to TWO MA FLIGHT ATTENDANTS in hushed tones and -- All three look up at Charlie. He immediately faces front -- nervous. TIGHT on him. He turns back -- takes another peek -- (CONTINUED)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  52.
ALL THREE FLIGHT ATTENDANTS are heading back up the aisle towards him -- Charlie quickly undoes his seatbelt, gets up in one swift motion --
Sir? Excuse me -- But Charlie's already moving fast down the aisle -- and h brushes by JACK, getting up from his own seat --
Sorry... And as Charlie moves on, we can just hear behind him --
Guess he really had to go. Charlie arrives at the lavatories -- but they're both occupied.

-- Bugger -—- -- And so he KEEPS MOVING, through BUSINESS CLASS -- cros to the other side of the plane -- he keeps going, into FI CLASS -- he turns back to see the THREE FLIGHT ATTENDANTS heading for him -- and the PLANE SHAKES. Just a little. N big deal. DING -- "FASTEN SEATBELTS" LIGHTS UP as Charlie reaches the FRONT LAVATORY, enters --
Ladies and gentleman, the pilot has turned on the fasten seatbelts sign -- please return to your seats with your seatbelts fastened...
Charlie is FLIPPING OUT. CAMERA is in here with him, TIGH CLAUSTROPHOBIC as he PULLS OFF HIS SHOE -- reaches into h SOCK as suddenly there's a KNOCK ON THE DOOR --
Sir? Are you all right? Charlie ignores her, still digging in his sock... finally pulls out a ROLLED UP BAGGIE containing a BROWN POWDER. KNOCKING MORE INSISTENT NOW... (CONTINUED)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  97 98 99 10 53.

Sir, I'm going to have to ask you to open the door... Charlie holds the baggie up... looks at it longingly. Thi physically PAINS him. But he turns around and drops it in the TOILET. The baggie rests on the METAL DROP-PLATE as..
(firm) Open the door now, sir. Charlie takes one last look at his stash, TIGHT SHOT as h reaches for the FLUSH LEVER and...

head_text.subj: THE PLANE SUDDENLY DROPS TWO HUNDRED FEET -

text: FALLS out of the bathroom -- and in the TERRIFYING JOLTS the last minutes of the flight, he falls back to --
-- FALLS to the floor and CRAWLS back through the MASSIVE PANDEMONIUM -- gets into a free chair -- BUCKLES UP and w TIGHT on his TERRIFIED EYES as we: CUT TO BLACK.
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  54.

101 EXT. “BASE CAMP” - CRASH SITE - DAY 101 CHAOS. We drop right into the middle of a BRAWL. CLOSE ON THE FIGHT as Sawyer and Sayid WRESTLE. It’s PANDEMONIUM. A GROUP of twenty or so stands around, watch the brutal fight --
OF... DON’T!
ACROSS THE CAMP Jack, Kate and Charlie emerge from the jungle, see all this --
What -- ? But Jack is already pulling his pack off, immediately ent the fray, pulling the men apart --
-- All right, ENOUGH!

I’ve had enough of this guy! You've had enough of me?! If You_accuse me of being a the shoe fits, buddy! Look criminal?! What next? I around! They all know it’s suppose you think I am you! I’m just the only one responsible for the crash! SAYING it!
HEY! What the hell --? Michael is here, holds up the pair of CUFFS --
My kid found these out in the jungle. On Jack. Kate. Charlie. All digesting this as...

(finger in Sayid’s face) And this guy was in the back row of business class the whole flight. Never got up. Hands folded under his blanket. And for some crazy reason -- I’m just pointing this out -- the guy I saw next to him didn’t make it. Do the math -- (MORE) (CONTINUED)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  101 55.
(nose to nose with Sayid) You're the prisoner, muchacho.

Thank you so much for observing my behavior so very carefully -- You think I didn’t see them pull you out of line before -- If you do not take your we boarded? finger out of my face -- -- Oh, please -- bring it-- And they’re about to go at it all over again when --
And they do. All eyes on Kate. Strong. Defiant. Angry.

We actually DO have bigger problems than this. (beat, pulls the TRANSCEIVER from Jack's pack) We found the transceiver. But it’s not working. Can anybody help...? A beat. Then, of all people, Sayid steps forward. Turns back, looks directly at fuckin’ Sawyer.
Yes, I might be able to.
Oh yeah, good! This guy! Perfect! Let’s trust him -- !
Hey -- we’re all in this together, man. Let's try to treat each other with --
Shut up, lardo.
HEY -- Give it a break.
(fuck you) Whatever you say, Doc, you're the hero. And Sawyer walks off, passing Jack, BUMPING him as he goe Jack watches him, not liking him one bit -- (CONTINUED)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  101 102 103 56.
You found the cockpit? Were there any survivors? Kate and Charlie exchange a look. Turn their eyes to Jack who meets their gaze. A beat. Then:
No.
(re: transceiver) It’s dual-band. Military spec. Broadcasts full-range, far as I can tell. Chances are the battery is good, but the radio... it is dead.
-- Can you get it to work?
(stares at it, feels pressure) I need some time. Kate nods -- Sayid walks off -- just as Rose moves to Jac saying quietly:
That man with the metal in his side -- he looks bad. Takes a beat for Jack to hear this -- but he finally does Jack looks at Kate for a moment -- then heads off. HOLD O Kate, who stands there, alone.
The broken transceiver, being OPENED. We are:

Sayid’s right at the edge of the fuselage, sitting on wreckage, using TWEEZERS and a found SWISS ARMY KNIFE to apart and examine the transceiver. Checking the internal connections. After a beat, Hurley arrives, sitting across from him. Saying one word, the sub-text being, “What a fucking pric
(re: Sawyer) That chain-smoking jackass. (CONTINUED)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  57.
Sayid glances up, nods: no kidding, then goes back to the radio. Understatement of the day:
Some people have problems.
Some people have problems. (then) Us. Him.
(amused) Us him. Hurley smiles back. Then:
You're okay. I like you.
(considers Hurley) You're okay, too.
Hurley.
Sayid. As Sayid works:
How d’you know how to do all that?
I was a Military Communications Officer.
Yeah? (then) Y’ever see battle?
Oh yes. (then) I fought in the Gulf War.
No way. I have a buddy, fought over there. He was in the 104th Airborne. Where you in the Air Force? Army? (CONTINUED)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  103 104 105 58.
(looks at him) The Republican Guard. And Hurley looks at him... realizing that holy shit... he just bonded with the enemy...

LONG LENS, CLOSE ON KATE, standing alone in a lagoon, out sight of the others. Her duffel bag on the shore, she wea only her underwear and tank-top in the water, cleaning herself off, using a shirt as washcloth. As she does this, she CRIES. Letting out all of the emoti that’s been building. We HOLD on her. This moment a catharsis for us as well. And we HOLD on her long enough to see her pull it togethe Finding her strength again. Staring off, knowing that somehow she has to keep moving forward.

(in KOREAN) -- Excuse me -- -- And Kate turns to see Sun standing there -- and Sun is slightly embarrassed as she points back, toward the wreck SUN (CONT’D) (in KOREAN) -- I believe they are finished. They need you. And Sun moves away.
Kate returns, dressed now -- as Sayid finishes wrapping t radio in black electrical tape.
-- Is it working?
Seems to be -- except we’re not picking up a signal.
-- Why would we need to pick up a signal, aren’t we sending one -- ? (CONTINUED)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  105
And Sayid Currently, 59. 105

-- Yes, but it’s a “transceiver” -- it transmits and receives. Which means you can also read the level of other signals that you are picking up. (shows her) What you want is to see little bars. Right here. shows her where RECEPTION BARS would normally be. there are none.
The little bars would show that the radio is getting reception. Meaning we'd be in range of another radio. There are no bars here.
...So the radio’s worthless.
-- We could broadcast blind. Hope that someone... maybe a ship, somewhere, picks up our distress call. But that would be a waste of the battery. Which might not last for long.
We need the bars.
We need the bars. (then, with a thought) It is unlikely, but perhaps worth a try.
-- What.
Sending a signal from high ground.
(uh-oh) .+-How high? And Sayid’s eyes flick over Kate’s shoulder as... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  60.

Following Sayid’s gaze. And CAMERA SLOWLY FOLLOWS KATE HE AS SHE TURNS, REVEALING -- the ENORMOUS MOUNTAINS that ho above them. Scary high. And with the next part of their mission now before them... CUT TO BLACK.
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
Jack examines SHRAPNEL MAN. His condition has worsened considerably -- skin taking on a yellow hue. Shallow breaths. As Jack delicately looks at the wound --
How is he? Jack glances over his shoulder, sees Kate. Eyes go Shrapnel Man. Shakes his head: not good. And she caring, nervous for the Man:
.»+.-Can you do anything?
I can pull out the shrapnel.
...-But yesterday you said --

-- I know. But that was yesterday. (then) I was hoping he’d be at a hospital by now. (beat) We leave him like this... he’ll be dead within a day. If I open him up... and if I can control the bleeding... and if he doesn’t go into sepsis -- and if I can find some antibiotics... he might be all right. But there’s no way of knowing until I see what kind of damage there is in there. (sees she’s freaked; a morose joke) Hey -- at least he’s unconscious. Kate absorbs this. A lot going on behind her eyes. almost see her make a decision. Then --
I’m going on a hike.
Sorry? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca 107 back to asks, We can (CONTINUED)
y.com/library  62.
We fixed the transceiver, but we can’t use it, not from here. If I --
-- Kate -- wait a second --

You’re the one who said we had to get out a signal -- -- Yeah, and we do, but I -- Someone has to -- and it don’t want you going in can’t be you, not with what there. he needs -- -- I want you to wait for me - -- No -- = -- There’s not time -- we -- Kate -- obviously need to send out a signal sooner than later -- -- Hold on a second -- you -- Yes I did, what makes you Saw what that thing did to think you’re any safer on the the pilot -- beach than you are in the jungle? Well. That’s logic that even Jack can’t argue with. He looks at Shrapnel man, knowing he has to stay --
Wait for me. I don’t know how long this‘1l take --
Sayid says the battery won’t last. Jack looks at her. Knows he can’t stop her.
If you hear anything. Anything. (beat) Run.
You know I will.
Good luck. Kate throws another look at Shrapnel Man -- intense. Connected. Somehow doesn’t want to leave him. Then:
You too. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  108 109 110 63.
The sea urchin gets CUT with a found POCKET KNIFE. REVEAL that we are:

At the shore. Sun kneels on the sand, cutting the sea urchins for food prep on a large ROCK. Jin stands beside her, holding an airplane FOOD TRAY, collecting the cut pieces. Once she's done, Jin takes the newly-cut pieces and adds to the tray. Sun reaches to take one of the pieces off the rock -- cle just trying to help -- but Jin actually slaps her hand, putting the piece onto the tray himself. She reacts -- obedient and accepting as Jin walks off with the tray. TI ON SUN as she watches him go. And in a private moment of defiance -- her eyes holding o her husband as he walks off -- SHE UNDOES THE TOP BUTTON HER _ BLOUSE. A WIDE SHOT of the image -- the complicated couple with t culturally-formed dynamic framed majestically by the incredible tropical terrain.
Hurley stands in the water, cleaning one of his shirts. After a long beat, Jin approaches with the tray. When Jin speaks, it's terse. Seemingly cold. And, of course, not i English:
(in KOREAN) I have food. Here. Try this. Hurley turns, sees Jin.
S'up.
(in KOREAN) Try this. Sea urchin, it's good, it'll keep you alive. Hurley takes a beat to understand what he's suggesting. (CONTINUED)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  110 111 112 64.
-- What. That? What, eat that?
(in KOREAN) It's food, there's enough for everybody.
Dude, guess what, I'm starving. But I am not nearly that hungry. No. (slow, louder) Thank you. No way. No. And Hurley turns back. Jin, finally realizing he's being rejected, walks off.
A page turns. It's THE FLASH. The text -- all dialog balloons, everything -- are in SPANISH.
Walt lies here, reading. Angry. Vincent's LEASH nearby. H turns the page. After a beat, Michael comes. Lies beside him. Eyes the comic. A beat.
..-That comic's in Spanish. (beat, knowing) «--D'you... read Spanish--?
No. (then) I found it. Michael just nods. Nothing's working. Takes a moment.
Esta ese libro bueno, pequefio hombre? (nothing from Walt) That was... I was kidding. (beat) Tell me about your school -- you go to school?
Yeah, I go to school.
...Though maybe ‘cause you travelled so much that y-- (CONTINUED)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  112 113 65.
I go to school. A beat. Nothing's working. Then:

Tell you what. When we get home... I'll get you another dog. And Walt looks back at his father. These words have the opposite of their intended effect -- they tell the kid th his dog is dead. And furious -- on the verge of tears -- Walt gets up and heads off. Michael watches him go, his e closing. Somehow he's fucked it up again.
Sayid puts the TRANSCEIVER in a plastic bag, then wraps i a beach towel. Nearby, Kate fills an empty water bottle w RAIN WATER collected on the TARP. She seems determined he Driven.

The others. They've heard about the thing you saw. The pilot. (off Kate's surprise) I understand why you and the doctor decided not to frighten us, but your English friend is telling anyone who will listen. (beat; grim) They think we are insane for going back in there. Kate hesitates. Then --
If he told you about the pilot, he told you what the pilot said. The rescue people -- they're looking in the wrong place. They're not gonna find us. Sayid nods. But his eyes stay on her. Curious --

I don't like it here. But you... you don't like it here even more than I do. (off her look) I agree, sending a signal from high ground -- this is something we need to do. (beat) But your... willingness to go back in. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  113 114 115 116 66.

After you saw... whatever it is you saw. It is either impressive. Brave. Or something else... I can't really understand. Sayid's looking at her now -- with those deep eyes -- alm as if looking into her soul... and God, it unnerves her.
A hand unrolls a sandwich bag containing an ounce of BROW POWDER.

With the crash site in the distance, Charlie -- sweating, slightly shaking -- has found some privacy here. And good thing: Charlie takes a pinky nail-full of the powder and SNORTS it. We're TIGHT ON HIM as we watch its effects: Charlie calms "evens out" almost instantly. He closes the bag, rolls it -- feeling much better about himself now --

TIGHT ON THE FACE OF A MALE FLIGHT ATTENDANT. Lying DEAD, eyes open, facing us. SLOWLY DOLLY and RACK FOCUS TO REVE SHANNON, sitting a few feet away in the sand. She stares the corpse, hugging her knees, quiet and nervous. The first dead body she's ever seen. And she just stares the thing, until Boone slowly walks up behind her. A beat
..»-What the hell are you doing. She just stares. Then, quietly:
...I think I was mean to him.
(beat) ..-What?
He was the guy.
What guy? (CONTINUED)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  67.
The guy at the gate. The guy who wouldn't give us our seats. (beat) In first class. Finally she looks at Boone.
Remember him? And Boone's staring. Christ, he does remember. Her eyes g back to the body. Realizing, she says, sotto:
He saved our lives. This morbid moment makes Boone very uncomfortable:
Shannon, come on, we're trying to clear the wreckage why don't you help out. But she doesn't turn away.
Come on, you're being worthless over here. That makes her turn to him, hurt, pissed off:
.--I'm being what?
-- Well come on, you're sitting on your ass staring at bodies -- that isn't--
Hey, I've been through a trauma, okay--?!
-- We've all been through a trauma! The difference is that since the crash you've actually given yourself a pedicure! (CONTINUED)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
You know what? It's so easy to make fun of me -- and you're good at it, I get it -- well screw you -- you don't know the first thing about what I'm thinking -- -- No you don't! 68. 116
-- I'd rather not waste my time making fun of you! I wish I didn't have any reason to! Yeah, it is easy! I have a better idea than you think I do -- -- No? Okay, Shannon, what are you thinking?
As Shannon's eyes flick over Boone's shoulder -- and we R FOCUS past Boone to the distance, where Kate and Sayid pa up to go.
I'm going with them. On the hike. A beat. Then -- Boone just laughs.
I'm going.
Oh yeah?
(fuck you) Yup. She grabs her WINDBREAKER, walks past an incredulous Boon
-- No you're not. (she doesn't stop.) Shannon!
As Kate and Sayid finish ZIPPING PACKS as Shannon, then Boone, arrive --
I'd like to come with you.
Thanks, but we're -- (CONTINUED)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  118 69.
She's not going. (sharp, to Boone) (to Kate et al) -- The hell I'm not -- -- She doesn't want to go -- she does this -- -- You don't know what the hell I "do"!
She postures -- makes choices just to infuriate her family-- which at the moment is me --
Shut-up and stop trying to be charming-- (to Kate, et al) I'm coming with you.
I'm not sure that's a good idea --
What're you -- like, two years older than me? Please. (turns to Charlie, who arrives) You're going, right?
-- Where, on the hike? Are you?
Yup.
-- Yes, I'm going. Definitely.
(firm, no time) Look, everybody can come. (heaves her PACK onto her back) But we're leaving now. And Kate walks off. Shannon looks to Charlie, slightly ta aback by Kate. Says quietly:

You couldn't tell from that, but she's quite nice, really. Shannon heads off. Boone, annoyed, follows. Then Charlie and Sayid. A LONG SHOT of them walking off -- then PULL BACK TO REVE we're with: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  119 120 70.

Sawyer watches them go as he sits on part of the shattere wing, near the remains of one of the enormous engines. He taking final drags on a cig. In general, a "fuck 'em all" attitude. After a beat, something weighing on his mind, he pulls hi wallet from a back pocket. Opens it. Pulls out a folded piece of paper. Unfolds it. TIGHT on Sawyer's face as he re-reads the page. And slowly... his face changes. His eyes awash in concern and, more surprisingly, vulnerability. He just stares at mysterious letter... his eyes actually WELLING UP with wh he reads. Finally, quickly, he re-folds it -- puts it back in his wallet, more anxious and troubled than we've seen him. He finishes the cigarette and puts it out on the damn airplane that brought him here. He gets up and moves off, quickly, after the others.

On Kate, with Sayid at the head of the group. Charlie, Shannon and Boone behind her in that order. They're just entering the jungle -- the growth gets thick quickly. And now we CUT BACK TO SAWYER, who moves quickly, determi through the jungle -- passing Boone, Charlie, Shannon -- Sayid and KATE, who he looks at, walking with her for a moment. Their eyes lock. She's surprised -- and not pleased.
Decided to join us?
Yeah, looks like it.
What changed your mind?
(mind your own business) I'm a complex guy, Sweetheart. (CONTINUED)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  71.
And Sawyer keeps walking, taking the lead. Kate wanting t tell him off -- but not. And we...

WIDE SHOT. Spectacular view. Our SIX HIKERS (Kate, Sayid, Charlie, Shannon and Boone, with Sawyer at the front, hac away plants with a found stick) trudge through the jungle the base of the MOUNTAIN. The hike isn't any fun. Plus, it's HOT. Also, they're scared. Kate especially -- lookin around with concern as they walk. Afraid that, at any moment, that Thing might show up to end their lives. Now WE FAVOR Shannon and Charlie, who walks beside her:
Y'ever heard of Drive Shaft?
..-What, the band?
Yeah.
(not a fan) Yuchhh.
Right.
Why?
Nothing. Horrible.
Do you have one of their songs stuck in your head--
-- Uh, yeah, sort of--
-- God, I'm sorry.
(laughs it off, dying) Yeah. Me too. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  122 123 124 72.
Back near the fuselage, Jack approaches Hurley --
I need some help.
-- Okay --
I need you to help me go through the luggage -- I need any prescription medication you can find -- especially any drugs that end with "mycin" or "cillin"-- those are antibiotics--
-- What's this for?
Please just do it -- you'll see.
TIGHT ON A SHAVING KIT. Jack's hands UNZIP it. Pulls out DISPOSABLE RAZOR.
Jack, disappointed, puts the shaving kit back in the bag he TURNS, opens another bag. And he notices MICHAEL, sitt nearby among the bags, staring off. As Jack goes through another bag, he asks:
..-How's your son? Michael looks up, surprised.
Walt? Yeah, I think he'll be all right.
How old is he?
Nine. (then, suddenly) Ten. (CONTINUED)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  124 125 126 73.
Jack glances at Michael, then finds something in the lugg It's another SHAVING KIT. As he UNZIPS it, starts to go through the contents --
Walt's more worried about his dog than anything. It was on the plane, so... Kids, you know. They're --
-- Was it a white lab?
(stunned) ...Yeah.
-- Yeah, I saw him yesterday. In the jungle.
-- What? Where?
Over there, hundred yards in or so. He looked good. And Jack pulls out a STRAIGHT RAZOR. He snaps open the blade. Tests its sharpness with his finger.
-- What was that thing you saw. In the jungle -- what was it? Jack folds the razor shut.
I have no idea. And Jack walks off. Michael looks toward the jungle. Sigh burdened with a task he doesn't want to accept: going int the jungle after that damn dog.
EXTREME CLOSEUP of a mini-travel MAGNETIC BACKGAMMON SET. Hands setting up the pieces.
It's Locke, setting up the game. After a long beat, ina WIDE SHOT, Walt comes into frame, watching Locke. (CONTINUED)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  126 74.
A long beat of silence. Finally, Locke asks, without ever looking up:
Do you play? A beat.
Nope. (long beat) -..-What is it? Is it like Checkers? As odd as Locke seemed around the adults, he almost seems normal now. A bizarre child-like honesty that makes him accessible to Walt.
Not really. (looks up) It's a better game than Checkers. And after a beat, Walt moves closer to Locke. Watches.
Do you play checkers with your pop?
(long beat) No. (beat) I was in Australia with my mom.
You have no accent.
Yeah, we move a lot. (beat) She got sick. She died. So. Locke looks at the kid. You sorta wish he weren't.

You're having a rough month. Matter of fact. Not talking down to the kid. And Walt appreciates that. Locke turns his attention back to the board. Slowly and gently continues to set up the board, pushing the small black and white tiles onto their starti points. The effect is almost mesmerizing -- (CONTINUED)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  126 75.
Backgammon is the oldest game in the world. Much older than chess. Archaeologists found sets when they excavated the ruins of Ancient Mesopotamia. Would you like to guess how old they were?
A hundred years?
Five thousand years.
(whispers to himself) ...Five thousand...
...That's older than Jesus Christ. Which doesn't really land for Walt. But he asks:
Did they have dice and stuff?
Yes. But theirs weren't made of plastic. (then) Their dice were made of bones.
(slightly nervous) Cool. Walt watches carefully as Locke picks up one WHITE piece one BLACK one. Folds them into his CLASPED hands and gent shakes...

The Persians called it "Takhteh Nard" which means "Battle on Wood". Two players. Two sides. One is light. One is dark. Locke extends his closed fists, offering them to Walt. Wa considers... deliberates. Then taps his finger on Locke's right hand. He slowly opens one. We don't get to see it, Walt does. And now that distracted creepy grin is back. (CONTINUED)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  126 127 76.
Walt. (beat, sotto) ...You wanna know a secret? HOLD ON the boy, staring at him... intrigued...
Back at the beach, Claire sits in the First Class seat, writing in a journal. Sad. Scared. And after a beat, Jin is there, with a tray of sea urchins. She regards the plate.
».-.-Oh. No thank you. But Jin insists:
(in KOREAN) You will need to eat -- especially you, you should have some. She hesitates, but takes some. Chews some off. Eats it. And God, does she not like it. Jin watches her, nodding:
(in KOREAN) It's good, isn't it? And as she eats the horrible food, suddenly her face chan Like she just felt something. Jin looks on, concerned -- and Claire stands --
-- Oh my God --
(in KOREAN) -- What is it? Are you -- are you okay? And she suddenly SMILES -- beams -- THANK GOD, SHE'S FELT
-- I felt it! Come here -- feel this! -- And she takes Jin's hand -- which disturbs him to no e he doesn't like this situation at all -- especially what
does: PLACING HIS HAND ON HER BELLY --
(CONTINUED)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  127 128 77.

-- Do you feel that?! Feel (in KOREAN) that! It's a kick! That's a -- Excuse me, that's okay, I foot! Right there -- no don't need to -- I would wait, it's moving -- he's rather not -- no, that's all moving around -- he... I right, please let go of my guess I think it's a he... hand -- And Claire's laughing now at the relief -- her eyes teari up as she talks to her belly:
I felt you -- thank you -- thank you!
Another WIDE SHOT. Different area, some time later. And o GROUP arrives, hiking through. As they do:
Okay. Wide open space. (to Sayid) You should check the radio -- see if we're good.
We're not gonna have any reception yet --
-- Tell you what -- just try it.
I don't want to waste the batteries --
-- I'm not asking you to keep it on all day --
-- We're still blocked by the mountain --
-- Just check the damn radio!

If I just CHECK, we might not have any juice left when we get to -- A sudden RUMBLE -- they all turn to look toward the SOUND coming from the OVERGROWN GRASS FIELD -- something LOUD - something COMING, FAST -- and they all FREEZE, afraid -- (CONTINUED)
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  78.
-- The hell's that?
(quiet, sudden panic) -- oh God -- And they all turn to look -- to the distant, tall-growing GRASS -- PUSH IN on our characters -- KATE --
...Something's coming -- Then we SMASH CUT TO:
-- We're RIPPING THROUGH THE GRASS at a SIDE-ANGLE -- A V

head_text.subj: OF THE LEGS OF THIS CHARGING, SNORTING BEAST

text: and just as fast we SMASH CUT BACK TO:
WHIP TO CHARLIE, TERRIFIED if under-stated:
